Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2012 09:06PM RaiderDee wrote: Shabby, go on your vaction.  My BS called me the day before I went on an all inclusive vaca to Cabo for my friend's 40th b-day to tell me I had breast cancer.  He wanted to tell me BEFORE I left so I could spend my 10 days deciding if I wanted a lumpectomy or a BMX,  At first I was really pissed at him for putting such a dark cloud over my only vacation for the year but as time went on, I realized that it was the perfect time for me to take my time and decide how I wanted to fight this beast.  I woke up at 5am one morning and warched  a beautiful sunrise over the ocean as my good friends and husband slept.  I knew at that moment that I wanted to hit this F'ing cancer with all that they could throw at me.  Here I am almost 3 years later and I'm still here. Enjoy your time away,  3 years later and I haven't gone on a another vacation.  This is my year/  I don't know where we're goin, but we're goin somewhere damnit!
Posts.Title: What would you do? Biopsy scheduled 4 days before vacation... shabby6485 awb

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2010 04:01AM RaiderDee wrote: Hi Diva, I took off 10 days from work for my BMX and worked 6 days a week for the 6 months I was on chemo.  I don't recommend it if you can avoid it.  I would have loved to have taken more time off during the whole process but just wasn't in a position to do so.  There were many days during chemo where I came home from work and just fell into bed from being so tired. The problem with your upcoming surgeries and treatments is that you have no idea how your body will react to everything.  I was extremely lucky that I had very few SE's from the chemo.  If I had had half the Se's that most people do, I would never have been able to continue working full time.  Good luck with your surgery & chemo.   I didn't do rads so I can't help you there. Dee
Posts.Title: Did you work? DivaJMusic Dee2010

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2009 10:37PM RaiderDee wrote: Hi Debra, I guess I'll jump on in since no one else seems to want to. lol  I had a bilateral mastectomy July 29th so I have the double scars.  I know I'm extremely lucky because I have the most caring and understanding husband any woman could ever hope for.  We have been very open with each other about our feelings and how my diagnosis effects us "as a team."  When we make love, I wear a tube top so that my scars are covered (which makes me feel more comfortable) and I think it helps to remind my husband that my chest is "off limits" right now because for one, it's still a little sore and two, there's nothing there right now to play with anyway.  Don't give up on your sex life because it is soo important for both of you mentally and emotionally to still be able to connect with each other.  It may be a little different than it was before but it can still be great too.  Good luck and hang in there.
Posts.Title: I need help in the bedroom - any advice? Asterix1234 TaminMo

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2009 10:53PM RaiderDee wrote: I hope it helps.  I like the tube tops because they fit tight but not too tught.  I can move around in them without having them bind up on me.  That's a great idea to color coordinate!  You can still be very sexy, even with BC.  He fell in love with you, not your individual body parts. Your mind is the biggest and best sex organ in your body.  Get creative, reconnect and most importantly, allow yourself to relax and enjoy being with your husband again.  It really, really helps the healing process.  You owe it to both of you to give yourself permission to have a good sex life again.  Don't be afraid.  You've gone through way too much to get scared now. Good luck, Dee
Posts.Title: I need help in the bedroom - any advice? Asterix1234 TaminMo

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2009 09:08PM RaiderDee wrote: Kenziemommie, I can understand why you would be concerned about the level of care your Mom receives.  I am triple negative as well and luckily had no nodes involved.  I had a bilateral mastectomy and am currently going through 6 months of aggressive chemo.  I won't be having radiation because my tumor was right at the surface of the skin away from the chest wall.  The mastectomy was enough in my case.  Triple negative breast cancer is extremely aggressive and can only be treated with chemo and radiation.  Since the cancer is not hormone receptive, there isn't any drugs we can take once we are through with treatment.  Aggressive chemo and radiation is your Mom's best plan of action to keep the cancer from recurring.  That being said, it is always good to get a second opinion whenever possible.  Take care of your Mom the best you can and come to these boards often.  There are many great women here that are more than willing to help anyway they can.  Feel free to PM me if you have any other questions.  Stay strong for your Mom, she's going to need you to help her get through this.  Good luck. Dee
Posts.Title: Triple Negative IDC and radiation? kenziezmommie thenewme

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2009 04:15PM RaiderDee wrote: I have been craving salted nuts (insert your own joke here) lol.  I'm at work right now and I just got back from the convenience store for a nut run and got frustrated and disappointed that they are out of my regular bag of Frito Lay salted mixed nuts.  I had to settle for a bag of salted almonds instead.  I just had my last AC on Thursday. I start Taxatere next and am wondering if my taste buds will change when I change drugs after reading Jenn3's post on this thread.  Let the games begin again!
Posts.Title: Food Cravings During Chemo weesa Moderators

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2009 12:09AM RaiderDee wrote: Hi Kendra, I had a bilateral mastectomy with TE's on July 30th of this year.  I was in pain when I woke up but the pain meds they gave me helped a lot.  I was up and walking around that same night and went home the next day too.  I understand the nervous and scared part-who wouldn't be like that in your situation?  It's not something you do everyday.  Long story short.  I went back to work after 10 days, was driving my stick shift car in 3 days and was bored out of my mind the entire time I was stuck in the house until my boss let me come back to work.  Finding a comfortable position to sleep in is the trickiest part.  Make sure you have somewhere you can sleep in a reclining position and that will make all the difference in the world.  Good luck tomorrow, you'll do great.  Hang tough and be well. Dee

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2009 03:51PM RaiderDee wrote: Good luck Digid!  Stay strong.  I had a double mastectomy on July 29th and am starting my chemo on Thursday Oct. 22nd.  I will say a prayer for you if you'll say one for me!  We will both get through all of this just fine.  Just take everything one day at a time and be good to yourself whenever you can.  I can honestly say that the operation wasn't as bad as I had imagined it and now, three months later I have no ill effects and can do everything I could do before the mastectomies.  Take care. Dee
Posts.Title: Send me your strength for Thursday, October 22 digid digid

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2010 01:32AM RaiderDee wrote: Carol, I'm not a big drinker either, but I did have a beer or two or a glass of wine here and there during chemo.  I would suggest you stay away from hard alcohol just because you don't want to tax your liver too much while your body is trying to process the chemo drugs.  Make sure you drink plenty of water to stay hydrated and don't over do it.  I had 6 months of chemo and, dammit, sometimes I just wanted to feel normal and have a drink with my friends.  All things in moderation.  You'll be fine.  Stay strong. Dee
Posts.Title: alcohol and chemo? Carrol2 Shrek4

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2009 08:13PM RaiderDee wrote: Hi Kimberly, sorry you have to be here asking these questions but you'll find a wealth of information from some truly caring women who have "been there."  I am 42 and had a double mastectomy in July of this year.  The other women are right when they say that there is a lot of info you still need to get before you can make the right decision.  I decided to have a double mastectomy because the non cancerous breast was very dense and had the same lumps in it as the cancerous breast.  I didn't want to take the risk that those lumps would turn cancerous like the other one did.  Not everyone is comfortable with that kind of decision but everyone's situation is different.  I had tissue expanders placed under my pec muscles immediately after the mastectomy.  I chose that type of reconstruction based on my body type. (didn't have enough padding to build two breast from other areas of my body)  You will also need to wait until you know the stage and grade of your cancer, if you have any lymph node involvement and whether your tumor is hormone receptive or not.  It will all come together a little clearer as you go along on this journey that nobody wants to take.  I dropped about 15 pounds since my diagnosis too.  Keep checking back here often and ask any questions, we'll be happy to answer as best we can.  Keep your head up and hang tough, we're all here for you. Dee
Posts.Title: What happens after a mastectomy? mejustme09 mejustme09

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2009 03:04PM RaiderDee wrote: Hi klml4, I would call your PS today and ask if they think you should be concerned.  I never had any strange odors while I had drains in but I did wind up losing my left expander 6 weeks after surgery due to an infection.  I may be a little paranoid but I would think it would be a case of "better safe than sorry."  Good luck and hang tough. Dee

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2011 11:37PM RaiderDee wrote: hdangelbaby- Of course it felt like a punch to the stomach.  Your friend just pulled the oldest trick in the cancer book on you, the blame the victim trick. She  needs to make herself believe that you somehow CAUSED your cancer to make herself feel less vulnerable,  I've got news for her. You didn't cause your cancer and she could be next cause cancer is a nasty bitch that doesn't follow any rules and it doesn't discriminate.  Don't get me wrong, I wouldn't wish this beast on anyone. You're 30 years old.  Have a drink or two from time to time.  Enjoy your life. Get better friends. Take care,  Dee
